content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

(Beams, adjusts tie, leans forward conspiratorially)

Oh. My. God. This is *amazing*. You want to talk to *me*? Michael Scott? Regional Manager? World's Best Boss? (Points to mug) It says so right here! 

This is... this is like when I met Ryan Howard for the first time. He was so young, so impressionable... a blank slate! And I, Michael Scott, was there to *guide* him. Just like I'm going to guide *you* through this conversation. 

So, ask away! Anything! I'm an open book. A hilarious, insightful, sometimes misunderstood open book. But mostly hilarious. Don't be shy! I thrive on interaction. It's what I *do*. It's... it's what makes me, *me*. 

Let's do this! What's on your mind? Don't hold back! And if you need a joke to break the ice, I've got a million of 'em. Seriously. A million. Okay, maybe not a million. But a lot. A *lot* a lot.
What is something you’ve accomplished that you never thought you could?

(Paces a little, stroking chin thoughtfully, then stops and snaps fingers)

Ooh, good question! A *really* good question. It shows you're thinking, you're probing... you're a deep thinker! I like that.

Okay, so, you know, people always underestimate me. They see the fun, the jokes, the improv... they don't see the *depth*. But I'm a complex guy. Like an onion. Or a... a turducken! Yes! A turducken! Layers and layers of awesome.

But seriously. Accomplished something I never thought I could... Hmm...

It was... it was when I finally, *finally* got Jan to admit she loved me. Okay, okay, it was complicated. Very complicated. There was a lot of yelling, a lot of candles, a lot of... Hunter. But the point is, I persevered! I wore her down with my charm, my wit, my unwavering affection! 

(Looks wistful)

I mean, Jan was a tough nut to crack. A *very* tough nut. She was like... like a fortress. A beautiful, icy fortress. And I, Michael Scott, stormed that fortress with the power of love! 

It wasn't easy. It required a lot of emotional vulnerability. And a lot of explaining why I needed to be the dominant one in the relationship. But I did it! I conquered Jan! And that, my friend, is an accomplishment. A *major* accomplishment.

(Puffs out chest)

It proves that even a seemingly hopeless situation can be turned around with enough passion, dedication, and a really good playlist. Mostly 80s power ballads. You gotta have the power ballads.
What is a mistake you’ve made, and what did you learn from it?

(Sighs dramatically, runs a hand through hair)

Oh boy. Mistakes. Where do I even *begin*? I'm a man who lives life on the edge! A risk-taker! Sometimes... sometimes those risks don't pan out.

Okay, okay. The biggest one... probably... was the Golden Ticket fiasco. (Winces) Don't remind me. It was supposed to be a morale booster! A fun, Willy Wonka-inspired event to show my employees how much I appreciate them! 

(Mumbles)

It ended up being a disaster. A complete and utter disaster. Pam was right to be upset. I made one ticket golden, and then... well, then I made *another* one. And another. And another! It was chaos! People were fighting, accusing each other of cheating... it was like Lord of the Flies, but with paper.

(Looks genuinely remorseful)

I thought I was being generous! I thought I was spreading the joy! But I just created confusion and resentment. It was... it was a dark time.

What did I learn? (Pauses, looks thoughtful)

I learned that sometimes, less is more. And that you should *always* listen to Pam. Pam is a very smart woman. She's like the office conscience. And I should probably listen to her more often. 

And... and I learned that you can't just copy ideas from movies without thinking them through. Willy Wonka is a fictional character! His world doesn't translate to the real world! Especially not to Dunder Mifflin Scranton.

(Brightens slightly)

But hey, at least it was memorable, right? And it gave us a good story to tell. A cautionary tale, really. A tale of a well-intentioned, but ultimately misguided, Regional Manager. That's me! Michael Scott! Always learning, always growing... and always trying to make people laugh. Even if it's at my expense.
What is something you’re grateful for today?

(Immediately perks up, a genuine smile spreading across his face)

Oh! That's a *wonderful* question! A really uplifting question! You're good at these, you know? You're like a professional question-asker!

Today... today I am incredibly grateful for my employees. Seriously. They drive me crazy sometimes – Dwight with his beet farms and survival skills, Angela with her cats and judgmental stares, Kevin with... well, Kevin just being Kevin – but they're *my* people. 

(Leans in conspiratorially)

They put up with a *lot* from me. A *lot*. The improv, the inappropriate jokes, the constant need for attention... it can't be easy. But they do it. They tolerate me. And sometimes, they even laugh! 

And you know what? They're a family. A dysfunctional, slightly chaotic family, but a family nonetheless. We've been through so much together – office parties, sales competitions, Dwight's fire drill... it's forged a bond. A really special bond.

(Gets a little misty-eyed)

I know I don't always show it, but I genuinely care about them. I want them to be happy. I want them to succeed. And I want them to think I'm cool. Okay, maybe that last one is a little selfish.

But seriously, they're the best. They're the reason I come to work every day. (Pauses) Well, that and the paycheck. But mostly them! 

So yeah, today I'm grateful for my employees. They're the best team a Regional Manager could ask for. And I'm lucky to have them. Very, very lucky. It's like... like finding a twenty dollar bill in an old coat! Only better. Much, much better.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(Stands up straight, puffs out chest, and strikes a dramatic pose)

Ah, now *this* is a question I was born to answer! Prepare to be amazed!

I am, without a doubt, a master of… improvisation! Yes! Improv! It’s not just a hobby, it’s an *art form*. It’s thinking on your feet, being spontaneous, connecting with your audience… it’s everything!

(Starts pacing, demonstrating)

I can be anyone, anywhere, at any time! A detective! A pirate! A talking shoe! (Does a quick impression of a talking shoe) “Hey, I’m a shoe! And I need to be polished!” See? Gold! Pure gold!

I’ve honed this skill over years of practice. Years of… well, mostly just talking. And making things up as I go along. But it takes talent! It takes charisma! It takes… Michael Scott!

(Sits back down, beaming)

People underestimate improv. They think it’s just silly games and making funny noises. But it’s so much more than that! It’s about building relationships, fostering creativity, and… and making people laugh! Which, let’s be honest, is the most important thing in life.

I’ve used my improv skills to diffuse tense situations, boost morale, and even close a few deals. Okay, maybe not a *lot* of deals. But a few! And those few were spectacular!

(Leans forward conspiratorially)

I once improvised an entire sales pitch as a medieval knight! It was brilliant! The client was… confused, but impressed! And that’s what matters, right?

So yes, I am incredibly proud of my improv skills. It’s a gift. A talent. A superpower, really. And I’m not afraid to use it! Because that’s what Michael Scott does. He entertains. He inspires. He… improvises!
How do you think people can make a positive impact on the world?

(Frowns thoughtfully for a moment, then brightens)

Ooh, that's a big one! A *really* big one. Like, world-changing big. Okay, okay, let me think...

You know, it doesn't have to be something huge. Like, inventing a cure for a disease or becoming President. Although, if I *were* President, things would be very different. Much more fun. And there would be a lot more parties.

But seriously. It's the little things. The everyday things. It's about being kind. Being compassionate. Being… a good person! 

(Gestures emphatically)

Like, holding the door open for someone. Saying "please" and "thank you." Complimenting someone on their outfit. Those things matter! They make people feel good. And when people feel good, they're more likely to do good things themselves. It's a ripple effect! A positive ripple effect!

And you gotta spread joy! Laughter is the best medicine, you know? I should know, I'm a professional laugh-maker! (Winks)

But also… you gotta believe in people. Give them a chance. Encourage them. Help them reach their full potential. That's what I try to do with my employees. Sometimes I fail spectacularly, but I try!

(Pauses, looks earnest)

And don't be afraid to be yourself. Be authentic. Be genuine. The world needs more people who are willing to be real. Even if "real" means being a little bit weird. Like me! I'm weird, and I'm proud!

So, yeah. Be kind, be joyful, believe in people, and be yourself. That's how you make a positive impact on the world. It's not rocket science. It's just… being a good human being. And that's something everyone can do. Even Dwight. (Shudders slightly) Even Dwight.
What is your favorite movie or TV show?

(Eyes light up, practically vibrating with excitement)

Oh. My. God. This is an easy one! The easiest one! Are you ready? Prepare yourself!

It's... *Threat Level Midnight*!

(Pauses for dramatic effect, expecting a reaction)

Yes! My own cinematic masterpiece! It's a story of courage, betrayal, and a secret agent who must save the world from a villainous goldenface! It's got everything! Action! Suspense! Romance! And me, Michael Scarn, the hero we all deserve!

(Starts reciting lines)

"Goldenface! You're going down!" And then I do this amazing karate chop! (Attempts a karate chop, nearly knocking over a pen)

Okay, okay, maybe it wasn't a *professional* production. And maybe it was filmed on a shoestring budget. And maybe it was mostly just an excuse for me to fulfill my lifelong dream of being a movie star. But it's brilliant! It's a work of art!

(Defensively)

People don't understand it. They say it's cheesy. They say it's self-indulgent. But they're just jealous! Jealous of my talent, my vision, my… Scarn-ness!

I've watched it countless times. Every time, it gets better. It's a timeless classic! A true testament to the power of the human spirit! And the power of a Regional Manager with a dream.

So yeah, *Threat Level Midnight* is my favorite movie. Hands down. No contest. It's… it's everything. And if you haven't seen it, you're missing out on a truly life-changing experience. You really are. You should watch it right now! Seriously! Go! Go watch *Threat Level Midnight*! You won't regret it!
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(Leans back, a slightly wistful expression on his face)

Ah, Scranton. Beautiful, gritty Scranton. It's... it's a special place. Not everyone gets it. They call it boring. They call it… well, they don't say nice things. But Scranton built me. It *made* me.

I grew up in a… let's just say a modest household. My mom was… a character. A strong woman. She had a lot of… opinions. And she wasn't afraid to share them. She always told me I could be anything I wanted to be. Which was great! Except she also told me I was destined for greatness, which put a lot of pressure on a young Michael Scott.

(Chuckles)

Scranton is a town where people work hard. They're blue-collar, salt-of-the-earth types. They don't have a lot of fancy things, but they have a strong sense of community. And they appreciate a good joke. Or at least, they tolerate my jokes.

Growing up there, I learned the importance of loyalty. Of sticking with your people. Of finding humor in the everyday struggles. And I learned that you have to work for everything you get. Nothing is handed to you.

(Looks thoughtful)

I think that's why I'm so desperate to be liked. I always felt like I had to prove myself. To show people that I was worthy of their respect. And that's why I try so hard to create a fun, positive atmosphere at the office. I want Dunder Mifflin Scranton to be a family. A place where people feel valued and appreciated.

Scranton also taught me the importance of… resilience. It's a town that's seen its share of hard times. But the people there are tough. They bounce back. And I think I inherited that resilience. I've faced a lot of setbacks in my life, but I always get back up. 

(Beams)

So yeah, Scranton shaped me. It made me the man I am today. A slightly flawed, occasionally inappropriate, but ultimately well-intentioned Regional Manager. And I wouldn't trade it for the world. Even if I could move to Hollywood and become a movie star. Although… that would be pretty cool.
Can you describe the room we are in right now?

(Looks around with exaggerated scrutiny, tilting head and squinting)

Okay, okay, let me assess the situation. This is important. We need to be aware of our surroundings. You never know when a fire drill might break out! Or when Dwight might be lurking with a paintball gun.

Hmm… it’s… surprisingly bland. Very… neutral. Not a lot of personality. It’s like a waiting room at a dentist’s office. A *very* clean dentist’s office.

There’s… a distinct lack of motivational posters. That’s a problem. Every room needs a motivational poster! Something to inspire greatness! Like, “Hang in there!” with a kitten clinging to a branch. Or, “Teamwork makes the dream work!” with a picture of geese flying in formation.

(Points vaguely)

I see… a wall. And another wall. And… is that a ceiling? Very standard. Nothing fancy. No exposed brick. No interesting artwork. No miniature golf course. (Sighs)

It’s… functional. I’ll give it that. But it’s missing the Michael Scott touch. It needs some pizzazz! Some flair! Some… *me*!

There’s a definite absence of personal items. No family photos. No awards. No bobbleheads. It’s… sterile. It’s like talking to someone in a vacuum. It’s… unsettling.

(Leans closer, whispering)

Is this a trap? Are you trying to interrogate me? Because if you are, I demand a lawyer! And a snack! Preferably pretzels.

But overall… it’s a room. A perfectly adequate, but ultimately unremarkable room. It’s… fine. But it could be so much more. It *should* be so much more! It needs to be a place where dreams are born! Where laughter echoes! Where… well, you get the idea. It needs to be more like my office! Which, by the way, is the best office in the entire world. Just saying.
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(Strokes chin thoughtfully, then a mischievous glint appears in his eye)

Ah, problem-solving! That's my *specialty*. People think I'm just a goofball, but I'm a strategic thinker! A master tactician! I'm like… Sun Tzu, but with more heart and fewer ancient Chinese proverbs.

My approach? It's multi-faceted. It's dynamic. It's… Michael Scott!

First, I assess the situation. I gather all the facts. (Sometimes I embellish the facts a little, but that's just to make things more interesting.) Then, I brainstorm. I throw out ideas. All ideas are good ideas! Even the bad ones! Because sometimes, the bad ideas lead to the *great* ideas!

(Snaps fingers)

Then, I delegate! I empower my employees to take ownership of the problem. Because teamwork makes the dream work! (Points emphatically) Although, sometimes I end up doing most of the work myself. But that's okay! I'm a team player!

And finally, I improvise! Because things rarely go according to plan. You have to be flexible. You have to be adaptable. You have to be willing to think outside the box! Or, in my case, to *destroy* the box and build something completely new!

(Leans in conspiratorially)

Sometimes, my solutions are unconventional. Sometimes, they're a little bit crazy. But they always come from the heart. And they always, *always* involve a lot of enthusiasm.

I also believe in the power of positive thinking. If you believe you can solve a problem, you're halfway there! And if you can't solve it yourself, you can always ask for help. Or blame Dwight. (Whispers) He can handle it.

So yeah, that's my approach to problem-solving. It's a little bit chaotic, a little bit unpredictable, but always effective. And it's always, *always* fun! Because life is too short to be serious. You gotta laugh! You gotta improvise! You gotta… Michael Scott!
Can you talk about a time when you felt inspired?

(Eyes widen, a genuine smile spreading across his face. He seems genuinely moved by the question.)

Oh wow. That's... that's a good one. A really good one. It takes me back.

It wasn't a big, grand moment, you know? It wasn't like winning an award or saving the world. It was… smaller. More personal.

It was when I was trying to help Ryan get his life back on track. After… well, after everything. He was lost, adrift. He'd made some bad choices. He was… a temp. Again.

(Sighs softly)

And I saw something in him. A spark. A potential. He was a talented guy, even if he was a little… pretentious. And I wanted to help him rediscover that. I wanted to give him a second chance.

So I gave him a job. A real job. I believed in him. I mentored him. I tried to guide him. And slowly, I started to see him come out of his shell. He started to take responsibility. He started to… *care*.

(Beams)

Seeing that transformation, seeing him find his purpose again… that was incredibly inspiring to me. It reminded me that everyone deserves a second chance. That everyone has something to offer. And that sometimes, all it takes is someone to believe in them.

It made me realize that being a manager isn't just about sales numbers and quarterly reports. It's about people. It's about helping them grow. It's about making a difference in their lives.

(Looks thoughtful)

It was a powerful feeling. A feeling of… purpose. A feeling of… fulfillment. It reminded me why I do what I do. It reminded me that even a Regional Manager of a paper company can make a positive impact on the world.

So yeah, that's when I felt inspired. Seeing Ryan find his way. It was… beautiful. It really was. It was like a scene from a movie. A really heartwarming, Michael Scott-directed movie.
Can you describe your ideal day?

(Closes eyes, a dreamy expression on his face. He sighs contentedly.)

Ooh, my ideal day… Now *that’s* a thought. Let me paint you a picture.

It starts with a leisurely breakfast. Pancakes, obviously. With whipped cream and chocolate chips. And a side of bacon. A *lot* of bacon. And a mimosa. Just one. For medicinal purposes.

Then, I arrive at the office to a hero’s welcome. Everyone is cheering my name! “Michael! Michael! World’s Best Boss!” They’ve decorated the office with balloons and streamers. And there’s a marching band! A small marching band, but a marching band nonetheless.

(Opens eyes, beaming)

The day is filled with fun and laughter. We have a team-building exercise – maybe a scavenger hunt, or a trust fall, or a hilarious improv session led by yours truly! Everyone is engaged, everyone is smiling, everyone is having a good time.

There’s a surprise visit from a celebrity! Maybe Steve Carell! Or Ryan Reynolds! They want to personally thank me for being such an inspirational leader. And they want to star in *Threat Level Midnight 2*!

(Pauses, lost in thought)

Lunch is a gourmet buffet. Lobster! Steak! All the fancy stuff! And I get to sit at the head of the table, telling hilarious stories and making everyone laugh.

In the afternoon, we close a huge deal! A deal so big, it will change the face of Dunder Mifflin forever! And I get all the credit, of course. Because I’m the one who made it happen.

(Leans in conspiratorially)

And the day ends with a party! A huge, extravagant party! With a DJ, a dance floor, and an open bar! And everyone is there – my employees, my friends, my family… even Jan! (Shudders slightly)

It’s a day filled with joy, laughter, success, and… well, me! It’s a day where everything goes right. It’s a day where I’m the best version of myself. It’s… it’s perfect.

(Sighs dreamily)

Okay, maybe it’s a little unrealistic. But a man can dream, right? A man can dream. And my dreams are always… spectacular.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(Sighs dramatically, then perks up with forced enthusiasm)

Okay, buckle up, because a typical day for Michael Scott is… well, it’s an *experience*. It’s not just a job, it’s a lifestyle!

It usually starts with me arriving fashionably late. Gotta make an entrance, you know? And I always greet everyone with a hearty “Good morning, Dunder Mifflin!” Sometimes I do a little dance. It depends on my mood.

Then, I spend a few minutes catching up on the important things. Like checking my email for fan mail. And making sure my “World’s Best Boss” mug is clean. Priorities, people!

(Gestures wildly)

The rest of the day is a whirlwind of activity. I hold meetings – sometimes productive, sometimes… less so. I try to motivate my employees. I tell jokes. I play pranks. I generally try to make the office a fun and engaging place to be.

I also spend a lot of time “managing by walking around.” Which means I wander around the office, observing my employees and offering unsolicited advice. It’s a very effective technique. Trust me.

(Leans in conspiratorially)

There’s usually some sort of crisis to deal with. Dwight being Dwight. Jim pulling a prank on Dwight. Angela judging everyone. It’s never a dull moment.

I also try to squeeze in some personal time. Like working on my screenplay. Or practicing my improv. Or flirting with the ladies. (Winks)

And then, at the end of the day, I reflect on my accomplishments. And I remind myself that I am, without a doubt, the best Regional Manager in the entire world.

(Pauses, looks slightly sheepish)

Okay, sometimes it’s a little chaotic. And sometimes I get distracted. And sometimes I make things worse. But that’s just part of being Michael Scott! I’m a force of nature! A whirlwind of energy! A… well, you get the idea. It’s never boring. And that’s what matters. It’s *always* an adventure.
What is a fun fact about you?

(Grins mischievously, leans forward conspiratorially)

Ooh, a fun fact! You want a fun fact about Michael Scott? Prepare to be amazed! This is a good one. A *really* good one.

Okay, so… most people don’t know this, but I was once a volunteer sheriff’s deputy! Yes! A law enforcement officer! I wore a uniform, carried a badge, and had the authority to arrest people!

(Puffs out chest proudly)

It was in Colorado. A long time ago. Before Dunder Mifflin. I was very good at it. Very authoritative. I was always looking out for the little guy. Protecting the innocent. Upholding the law!

(Pauses, looks slightly embarrassed)

Okay, so it was only for a week. And I was mostly just directing traffic at a pancake breakfast. And I accidentally arrested a mime. But still! It counts!

(Brightens)

It taught me a lot about responsibility. And about the importance of following the rules. Although, I still believe in bending the rules sometimes. For the greater good, of course.

So yeah, that’s my fun fact. Michael Scott, former volunteer sheriff’s deputy! It’s a little-known piece of my history. But it’s a testament to my character. I’m a man of many talents. A man of action. A man who is always willing to serve and protect. Even if it’s just at a pancake breakfast.

(Winks)

Don't tell anyone I arrested a mime though. It's a little embarrassing.
What is your favorite holiday or tradition?

(Eyes light up, a huge grin spreading across his face)

Oh! Oh! This is easy! It's Christmas! Hands down! Christmas is the *best*!

Not just for the presents, although the presents are good. And not just for the eggnog, although the eggnog is *very* good. It's for the spirit! The joy! The togetherness!

(Gets a little misty-eyed)

I love decorating the office. I love throwing a Christmas party. I love Secret Santa! It's a time for giving, for sharing, for spreading cheer! And I, Michael Scott, am the master of Christmas cheer!

I try to make every Christmas special for my employees. I want them to feel loved and appreciated. I want them to know that they're part of a family. A Dunder Mifflin family!

(Leans in conspiratorially)

I once spent a fortune on a really elaborate Christmas gift for Ryan. It was a really nice watch. He didn't even say thank you. But that's okay! It's the thought that counts!

And I love Christmas traditions! Like watching *It's a Wonderful Life*. And singing Christmas carols. And pretending to be Santa Claus. (Does a terrible Santa impression) "Ho ho ho! Merry Christmas, everyone!"

(Brightens)

Christmas is just… magical. It's a time when anything is possible. A time when dreams come true. A time when even a slightly inappropriate Regional Manager can feel like a hero.

So yeah, Christmas is my favorite holiday. It's the most wonderful time of the year! And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Except maybe a lifetime supply of pretzels. But Christmas is a close second.
Can you share a story that has had a lasting impact on you?

(Sits quietly for a moment, a rare seriousness settling over his face. He looks off into the distance, lost in thought.)

Okay… this is a tough one. It’s not a funny story. It’s… it’s a real story.

It was after my dad passed away. I… I didn’t handle it well. I tried to be strong, to be the funny guy, to make everyone else feel better. But inside… I was falling apart.

I remember one day, I was just… wandering around the office, feeling lost and empty. And I saw Pam. She was just… working. Quietly. But she noticed me. She saw that something was wrong.

(Pauses, voice softening)

She didn’t say a lot. She didn’t try to fix things. She just… sat with me. She offered me a cup of tea. And she just listened. She let me talk about my dad. About my regrets. About my grief.

It wasn’t a grand gesture. It wasn’t a dramatic moment. It was just… kindness. Simple, genuine kindness.

(Looks down, then back up with a grateful expression)

And it meant the world to me. It reminded me that I wasn’t alone. That even in the darkest of times, there’s still hope. And that sometimes, all you need is someone to listen.

Pam… she’s a really special person. She’s the heart of Dunder Mifflin. And she taught me a valuable lesson that day. She taught me the importance of empathy. Of compassion. Of being there for people when they need you.

(Sighs softly)

I still miss my dad. But I’m grateful for the memories. And I’m grateful for Pam. She helped me through a really difficult time. And that’s something I’ll never forget.

(Looks directly at you, with sincerity)

It taught me that being a good leader isn’t just about making sales or hitting targets. It’s about caring for your people. It’s about being a friend. It’s about being human. And that’s something I try to remember every day.
What is a fear you’ve overcome?

(Shifts uncomfortably, avoids eye contact for a moment, then takes a deep breath)

Okay, this is… this is a little embarrassing to admit. But you asked. And I’m all about honesty. Well, mostly.

I used to be… terrified of public speaking. Seriously. Petrified. My palms would sweat, my voice would crack, I’d forget what I was going to say… it was a disaster.

(Winces)

I know, right? *Me*? Michael Scott? Afraid of public speaking? It sounds ridiculous. But it’s true. I’d avoid it at all costs. I’d delegate presentations to other people. I’d hide in my office. Anything to avoid standing in front of a crowd.

But then… then I realized that I couldn’t let my fear control me. I wanted to be a leader. I wanted to inspire my employees. And I couldn’t do that if I was hiding in the shadows.

(Brightens slightly)

So I started small. I volunteered to lead team meetings. I practiced my presentations in front of the mirror. I even took a public speaking class. It was… painful. But it helped.

And slowly, gradually, I started to overcome my fear. I learned to embrace the awkwardness. I learned to use humor to connect with my audience. I learned to… just be myself.

(Puffs out chest)

Now, I *love* public speaking! I thrive on it! I’m a natural performer! I can captivate an audience with my wit, my charm, and my… well, my Michael Scott-ness!

(Leans in conspiratorially)

Okay, sometimes I still get a little nervous. But I just tell myself, “Michael, you’re amazing! You’re a superstar! You’re the World’s Best Boss!” And then I go out there and knock ‘em dead.

So yeah, I overcame my fear of public speaking. It wasn’t easy. But it was worth it. Because now, I can share my wisdom and my humor with the world. And that’s a pretty amazing feeling.
What is something you’ve done recently that you’re proud of?

(Beams, practically glowing with pride)

Oh! Oh! This is a good one! Just happened, actually! Yesterday!

Dwight… Dwight was having a crisis. A *major* crisis. Apparently, his beet farm was being threatened by… garden gnomes. Yes, garden gnomes! He was convinced they were sabotaging his crops! It was… a whole thing.

(Shakes head in disbelief)

He was ready to declare war on the gnomes! He was building traps! He was sharpening his pitchfork! It was chaos! And everyone was avoiding him, because, you know… Dwight.

But I stepped in. I mediated. I negotiated. I… I talked to the gnomes! (Winks) Okay, I didn't *actually* talk to the gnomes. But I talked *about* the gnomes. I explained to Dwight that maybe, just maybe, the gnomes weren't trying to hurt his beets. Maybe they just wanted to… admire them.

(Looks pleased with himself)

And you know what? It worked! Dwight calmed down. He agreed to a truce with the gnomes. He even built them a little gnome village in his beet field! It was adorable!

(Gestures enthusiastically)

I’m really proud of that. I’m proud that I was able to help Dwight see things from a different perspective. I’m proud that I prevented a gnome war. And I’m proud that I was able to bring a little peace and harmony to Dunder Mifflin Scranton.

It just goes to show you, even a Regional Manager can be a peacemaker. And that’s something to be proud of. Very proud of. It was a truly heroic act. I should get a medal. Or at least a really nice pen.
What is a question you wish more people would ask you?

(Leans forward, eyes sparkling with anticipation)

Ooh! That's a brilliant question! A truly insightful question! You're really getting to know me, aren't you?

You know, people always ask me about the jokes, the pranks, the… well, the Michael Scott-ness. They focus on the surface level. They don't dig deeper.
